description: On March 12, the Government of Slovenia adopted the decision to temporarily close kindergartens and schools between March 16 and March 29.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)

description: On March 12 at 6 p.m., Slovenia declares an epidemic. At the same time, the national emergency response plan is activated.

Slovenia bans aircrafts from Italian airports, in places where risk of infection is higher, from China, South Korea, and Iran. The ban applies from 10. 3. 2020 to 31. 3. 2020, with a possibility of extension. This does not apply to emergency and medical flights.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On 10 March, Slovenia advises citizens against travelling to the South Korean area around Daegu and Cheongju and against all but essential travel to other parts of the Republic of Korea.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 10, Slovenia advises "against all but essential travel to China and against all travel to the province of Hubei until further notice."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 10, the Slovenian MFA advises against all travel to Italy.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 10 March, the Slovenian MFA advised against all travel to Iran. Slovenian citizens temporarily staying in Iran are advised to leave the country as soon as possible.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Slovenian government adopted a decision to start carrying out border control checks in the vicinity of the border between Slovenia and Italy on 11 March 2020. This will include checking for negative SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) result certificates issued by a competent authority.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: On March 11, "Passenger train traffic between Italy and Slovenia has been suspended."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 16, the Slovenian Government bans international air transport in the Republic of Slovenia from March 17 until March 30.
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On March 24, Slovenia announces setting up of thirteen checkpoints at the border with Austria from March 25.  Entry to Slovenia will be permitted only to foreign citizens with a recent health certificate or to those with body temperature under 37.5C and no clear signs of respiratory infection. This excludes Slovenian citizens.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 28, Slovenia banned flights to and from non-EU countries until further notice while flights to and from EU destinations remain suspended until 13 April. UPDATE: Slovenia extended the air traffic ban adopted on March 17, non-EU air traffic will now be banned until further notice and flights to and from EU countries remain suspended until April 13.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On April 4, The Defence Ministry announced that the rotations of contingents of the Slovenian Armed Forces in international operations and missions planned in the next three months will not be carried out. The contingents which are currently abroad will need to extend their service for three months. Around 250 troops are deployed in Kosovo and eight in Mali.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On March 14, Slovenia announces a change in diagnostics, where the number of severely ill persons requiring hospital care will be monitored through testing, not the total number of infected persons.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On March 9, Slovenia announces that all preventive activities of health centres at Metlika, Novo mesto, Črnomelj and at Novo mesto general hospital will be suspended and all non-urgent specialist examinations will be rescheduled until further notice, except for acute illnesses and conditions that could lead to a deterioration of health. Visits to a personal doctor should be made by prior telephone appointment.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 12, Slovenia prohibits health staff from taking annual leave, restricts their right to go on strike and the right to participate in training and education provided in infected areas or areas at immediate risk of coronavirus outbreaks

description: On March 15, Slovenia allows the allocation of doctors without licenses to be published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Slovenia from March 15.

description: On March 12, Slovenia announced that "As of 16 March 2020, specialist examinations and surgical operations except cases rated as “emergency” or “urgent” or “express” will be cancelled. This will exclude oncology and pregnancy treatments. Wherever there is a possibility of e-consulting services, it should be used to the maximum extent."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 29, Slovenia announces the mandatory use of masks (or equivalents, such as scarves that cover the mouth and nose) and protective gloves in indoor public spaces.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 4, The Slovenian government restricted the usage of drugs containing chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine or azithromycin to make sure enough of those substances are available to patients who need them.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 23, the Slovenian government changed the methodology of testing. People over 60 and those with immune deficiencies and mild symptoms will now be tested. UPDATE: On March 23, Slovenia changed its testing methodology from testing only those hospitalised as adopted on March 14, to testing people over 60 and those with immune deficiencies and mild symptoms.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 15, Slovenia places a temporary ban on public transport of passengers, with the exception of auto-taxi services.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On 8 May, Slovenia announced that public transport will be relaunched on 11 May.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 12, the Civil Protection Service of the Republic of Slovenia was put in charge of coordinating the measures to combat the spread of the virus, in cooperation with the relevant departments.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 14, Slovenian "Prime Minister Janez Janša said that the Government established the crisis unit to contain and manage the COVID-19 epidemic at its first session [...]. The crisis unit will include support groups, the most important of which will consist of medical experts."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Slovenia sets up a call centre to assist inhabitants in finding information regarding the coronavirus.

On March 9, Slovenia announces that "all travellers crossing the Slovenian border will be informed via SMS notification of the preventive measures in force in this country regarding the coronavirus" and "leaflets containing coronavirus action instructions will be distributed to all Slovenian households via the Post of Slovenia."
On March 27, the Slovenian government announced all Slovenians returning from coronavirus hotspots would be put into state-administrated quarantine.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 27, the Slovenian government announced all Slovenians returning from coronavirus hotspots would be put into state-administrated quarantine.
type_sub_cat: Quarantine outside the home or government facility (i.e. quarantine in a hotel)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 29, Slovenia imposed a temporary general prohibition of movement and public gathering in public places and areas in the Republic of Slovenia and the prohibition of movement outside the municipality of permanent or temporary residence from March 30. UPDATE: Slovenia amended the rules on the temporary prohibition of movement and public gathering in public spaces. From March 30, additional measures have been taken, such as that people are not allowed movement outside the municipality of permanent or temporary residence, access to public spaces.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On April 3, the Slovenian Government announced a mandatory 14-day quarantine for most people entering the country from April 4, punishable by fines. It does not, however, apply to people who have to travel for work, those involved in cargo traffic or who are passing through Slovenia on their way to another country without staying overnight.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 15, Slovenia announces a temporary ban on the provision and sale of goods and services directly to consumers in the territory of the Republic of Slovenia from March 16 at 00.00. The temporary ban excludes remote provision and sale of goods and services to consumers and certain activities such as pharmacies, stores with food, shops with medical devices, petrol stations, banks, post offices, delivery services.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down

description: Slovenia amends the rules for the temporary prohibition of offering and selling goods and services as follows: "a) defines in detail a grocery store referred to in indent one of paragraph one of Article 2 of the Ordinance; b) adds stores selling animal food to the exceptions to the prohibition; c) temporarily determines the business hours of stores selling groceries and agricultural products, except for micro and small enterprises, sole proprietors and cooperatives.  A grocery store is a store that mostly sells groceries." UPDATE: Slovenia amends the rules for the temporary prohibition of offering and selling goods and services as follows: "a) defines in detail a grocery store referred to in indent one of paragraph one of Article 2 of the Ordinance; b) adds stores selling animal food to the exceptions to the prohibition; c) temporarily determines the business hours of stores selling groceries and agricultural products, except for micro and small enterprises, sole proprietors and cooperatives.  A grocery store is a store that mostly sells groceries."
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down

description: On April 4, The Slovenian Government adds florists and nurseries as exceptions to the its temporary ban on the provision and sale of goods and services. UPDATE: The Government allows florists' and nurseries to open, along with allowing construction work at sites not used as living spaces and where the workers have no contact with the clients.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is closed/locked down

description: On April 4, The Slovenian Government adds florists and nurseries as exceptions to the its temporary ban on the provision and sale of goods and services. UPDATE: The Government allows florists' and nurseries to open, along with allowing construction work at sites not used as living spaces and where the workers have no contact with the clients.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is closed/locked down

description: Minister of Health of Slovenia signs an Order banning gatherings of more than 500 people at public events in indoor public places.
The government of Slovenia recommends event organisers to ban events of fewer than 500 people from March 7.
Slovenia prohibits indoor public gatherings for 100-plus visitors from March 3., with the exception of shopping malls, small commercial venues, weddings, funerals and religious ceremonies.

On March 9, Slovenia announced that it will amend the Order prohibiting indoor public gatherings to reduce the upper limit from 500 to 100 people from March 10. UPDATE: On March 7, Slovenia banned mass gatherings in indoor public places to 500 people, on March 9 this has been amended to 200 people.

On March 9, Slovenia announces that employers should alert or urge workers who are ill to stay at home and follow instructions. Work from home is advised to the greatest possible extent. Non-urgent business trips are strongly advised against.

From March 19, grocery shops in Slovenia "must be open from 8am to 8pm, and for the first two hours, until 10am, groups particularly vulnerable to infections - the elderly, pregnant women and disabled persons - must be given priority."

On March 19, Slovenia announced that from March 20, "the movement and gathering of people in public places and areas in the Republic of Slovenia and access to public places and areas the Republic of Slovenia shall be prohibited until further notice."
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On March 29, Slovenia entered into force a law allowing a one-month suspension of a prison sentence and an early release of prisoners up to six months before the end of their sentence.

From March 30, pensioners in Slovenia will only be allowed into stores between 8am and 10am and will not be allowed into shops after 10am. UPDATE: Previously, grocery shops had to give priority during the 8-10am slot to older persons, the disabled and pregnant women. Now, this time slow will be reserved exclusively for these vulnerable groups while pensioners will not be allowed into shops after 10am at all.
